oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Correspondence between Mrs. John Trotwood Moore and Miss Susie Gentry
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Quilts; Quilting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two letters of correspondence between Mrs. John Trotwood Moore and her cousin, Susie Gentry. The first item of correspondence is from Susie Gentry to Mary Daniel Moore, written from Franklin, Tennessee, on May 28, 1934. In her correspondence, Gentry discusses the Natchez Trace Road, the Old Glory Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, the Colonel Thomas Hart Benton Chapter of the United States Daughters of the War of 1812, and an inkblot she has made to look like a boy. The second piece of correspondence is a response from Mrs. Moore, dated June 1, 1934. Mrs. Moore states that she didn't know what an artist Miss Gentry was until she saw her lovely quilt and the ink spot on her letter.

Mary Daniel Moore and Susie Gentry were cousins. Moore served as State Librarian and Archivist from 1929-1949. Gentry organized the Old Glory Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, the Colonel Thomas Hart Benton Chapter of Daughters of the War of 1812, and the Watauga Cumberland Settlers Association. She also served as an officer in the Colonial Dames.
